DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of pers notte for halfe of hys burgage in Crekelade.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270? Grant to Godstow, by Pers le notte, of half a burgage, to endow a wax-candle in the choir of Godstow.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of thys chartur is, þat pers le notte of hynintonHannington, Wiltshire. gafe, grauntid, & confermid with þis present wrytynge, to god & to þe churche of owre lady seynt Marye & seynt Iohn Bap|tiste of Godestowe & to þe mynchons þer seruynge god & to serue for euyr, for þe helþe of hys sowle, halfe of hys burgage þat he had in þe grete strete of Crekelade, with þe gardyn & with all his pertinences þer, þe whyche halfe of burgage is sette nyhe soppeham þe whyche adam helde vppon þe northe parte & halfe of þe burgage þat þe same Iohn helde vppon þe sowthe parte, to be had & to be holde, of hym & of hys heyrys, to þe seyde mynchons & to her successours, frely & quietly, pesibli & holly for euer, paynge þerof yerly to þe seyde Iohn & to hys heyrys or to hys assynys vj. d at to termys of þe yere, þat is to say, at hockedayHockday is 2nd Tuesday after Easter. iij. d, & at Mihel-masse iij. d, for all seruice, custome, & demaunde seculer, longynge to hym & to hys heyrys. He willid also & assynyd þat whatsoeuer þinge myht be leueyid of þe seyde burgage sholde be for þe sus|teynynge of a lyhte in wex a-fore þe cros in þe quere of þe monasteri of Godestowe. Also pers notte of hynynton & his heyrys or assynys warantiȝed acquited & defended to the fore|seyde Mynchons & to her successours or to her assynys þe foreseyd burgage, with hys pertinences, a geynyste all men & women for euyr, vppon all the goodys þat myht falle to hym & to hys heyrys by ony ryht in þe towne of Crekelade: & þat thys gyfte graunt warantiȝinge & confirmacion myht be stronge for euyr, he put to hys seele: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: A quite-clayme of william of driffeldeDriffield, Gloucestershire. of a mese in Crikelade.

ARGUMENT.P: 1277/8, Jan. 3. Sale to Godstow, by William of Driffield, of his interest in a mes|suage (no. 815). Purchase|money, £2.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis euydence is, þat william of driffeldeDriffield, Gloucestershire. lefte & quite-claymyd vtturly, of hym-selfe & of hys heyrys for euyr, to þe abbas of Godestowe & to the couent of þat place, all hys ryht & clayme þat he had, or myht haue in ony maner wyse, in a mese in þe towne of Crickelade, þe whyche he helde sum-tyme of þe fore-seyde Abbas in þe same towne, vndur þis forme: þat is to sey, þat noþer he, ne none of hys heyrys, ne no man in hys name, sholde aske afturwarde ony ryht or clayme of þe foreseyde mese, noþer to make no chalenge of ony dettes in þe whyche þe foreseyde Abbas or her baylifs were be-holde to pay to hym vn-to þat time þat þis present writinge was made. For the whyche quiete-clayme & relesynge of dette, þe foreseyde Abbas gafe to hym xl. shillings of siluer in warisone a-for-handys. In-to witnes þer-of he put to hys seele, þe date at EtonWatereaton, near Cricklade., þe moneday next a-fore þe twelfyth day, þe yere of oure lorde Mlo CC. lxxvijo.

DIV5.HEAD: A Charter of Margery Dyne, abbesse of Gode|stowe, I-made to Iohn maryner and to Anneys his wyf, for one Burgage in the towne of Crikelade.

ARGUMENT.P: 1328, April 26. Lease by Godstow, for two lives, of a 'bur|gage,' quit-rent, 5s., with obliga|tion to repair, and reser|vation of powers of distraint.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of this charter is, that Margery Dyne, abbesse of Godestowe, and the Couente of the same place, with one assent and consent, graunted, and lete, to Iohn Maryner and to Anneys his wyf, j. Burgage in the towne of Criklade, the which Geffrey North somtyme held, and hit is I-sette bitwene the strete that strecchith hit-self toward Chelesworth of the North parte and the Burgage of Iohn Bockare of the sowth parte: To be had and to be hold, with all his pertynentis, to the forsaid Iohn and Anneys, to all the terme of ther lyf, by seruyce therof dew and I-wonyd of right, yeldyng therof yerely to them and to ther successours v. shillings of yerely rente at iiij. termes vsuell of the yere, by evyn porcions, duryng the abouesaid terme. So natheles that the forsaid Iohn and Anneys his wyf shold susteyn the forsaid burgage thurgh all the terme
in al so good a state, or better, as they resceived hit. And Mar|gery Dyne, abbesse of Godestow, and Couente of the same place, and there successours, shold warantiȝe the forsaid Bur|gage, with his pertynentis, to the forsaid Iohn and Anneys his wyf, to the terme of ther lyf, as hit is abouesaid. And yf the said Iohn fayled or lakked in the forsaid vsuell termes, in parte or in all, of the paiyng of the said rente duryng the terme abouesaid, they bound them-self, and also ther catall (mevable and vnmevable) I-founde in the said burgage, to the distreynyng of the said abbesse and couente that shold be, tille hit were fully I-satisfyed to the same abbesse and Couente of the forsaid rente of v. shillings yerely also with the expenses and harmes, yf there were ony, or put to ony, by the occasion of the said rente not I-paid. Into witnesse of the which, & cetera. The date at Godestowe, in their Chapiter, the Tewesday next afore the fest of the appostles Philippe and Iacob, the second yere of the reigne of kyng Edward the thirde after the conquest.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur endentyd by-twe[ne] dame Mariery dyne Abbas & Iohn Mariner of Crikelade.

ARGUMENT.P: 1332, Oct. 21. Lease by Godstow to John and Alice Mariner for life-term, of a 'bur|gage' in Cricklade (no. 817), and, in Broad Blunsdon, a messuage, with pas|ture for one ox, and three acres arable. The land owes rent; three days reaping, with only food allowed; one day haying, with both food and drink allowed; and suit to court. Powers of distraint.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat Marierie dyne, Abbas of Godestowe, & þe couent of þe same place, with on assent & consent of here chapiter, toke, grauntid, & lete, to Iohn Mariner of Creklade & to AliȝAgnes, his first wife (no. 817), being dead, Mariner surrendered that lease, to obtain a like privilege for his second wife, Alice. hys wyfe, to þe term e of her lyfe & ouer on yer aftur þe decesse of her life, j. burgage I-sette in Creklade, by-twene þe borow of Iohn Buckar of þe on partye & þe lane þat is callid þe Ruthernslane of þe oþer parte; j. mese in brodebluntisdoun, I-sette by-twene þe mese of sire adam walrande, knyht, & þe mese of Iohn colcote; pastur of j. oxe in þe comune of þe same town; & iij. acris of arable londe lyinge in þe telþe of the same towne, of the whyche j. halfe acre lieth at harewell, & ij. rodys lien in þe longefurlonge, & ij. halfe rodys lien in þe brokeforlonge, & ij. halfe rodys strecchen to þe brobattes, & j. halfe acre lieth in Cranlekesforlonge by-twene þe londe of Iamys Geryssh & Nicholas Ingelonde, & j. halfe acre in westcrofterugge by-twene þe londe of Nicholas brayn & þe londe
of Iohn more, & j. half-acre lieth in the castle nyhe þe hyde: þe fore-seyde burgage, with þe pertinences, liberteis, & þe customys of þe foreseyde borow, to be had & to be holde; Also þe fore|seyde mese in brodebluntesdon, & iij. acres a-fore-namyd, with her pertinences; & Also þe seyde pasture of j. oxe, as hyt is put by-fore, to þe fore-seyde Iohn & to aliȝ hys wyfe, as longe as they liuid, of þe foreseyde Marierie & of her couent & her successours, frely, quietly, well & pesibly, paynge þerof yerely þorowe þe terme of here life, viij. shillings vj. d of rente, þat is to sey, for þe burgage a-fore-seyde v. shillings, & for þe mese & þe per|tinences a-fore-named iij. shillings vj. d of goode money; for all seruices seculer of þe fore-seyde borowe, at fowre vsual termys of þe yere, by euyn porcions; but þei shall repe yerly in heruyst'The Cestum yn heruyste off Blondon,' note in margin. by thre days, & they shall haue necessari of metis; & þey shall make hey & mow thorowe on day, & haue mete & drinke; & þey shall make sute of courte fro thre wokys vn-to thre wokys; so þat þe seyde mariery dyne & hyr couent sholde pay a yerly rente to the chyfe lordys of þe fee of the seyd burgage, þat is to sey, xvj. d by þe yere. Also þe seyde Marierye dine, Abbas of Godestowe, & her couent, warantiȝed [&] acquited þe fore|seyde burgage, Mese a-fore prefixid, pasture of j. oxe, with thre acris of londe a-fore-namyd, & with all þe pertinences in all places, to þe fore-seyde Iohn and aliȝ also longe as they liuen, in þe forme a-fore namyd; & yf þe fore-seyd Iohn or aliȝ hys wyfe fayle, in þe foreseyde vsuall termys, in parte or in all of þe payment of þe rent a-fore-seyde, durynge þe terme a-boue-sayde, þey bounde hem-selfe & all here goodys meuable & vnmeuable to þe distreyny[n]ge of þe seyd Abbas & couent, þat sholde be for þe tyme, tyl hyt were satisfied fully to þe same abbas & couent of þe fore seyde rent of viij. shillings vj. d, Also with harmis & expenses, if þei did, or sette ony, for þe cause of þe rent not payd. In-to witnes of þe same þynge, to þys wrytinge endentid þey sette to her comune sele, with þe selis of the seyde Iohn & aliȝ hys wyfe, eueriche a-geynyst oþer: þe date at Godestowe, in her chapitre, þe wodenesday next a-fore þe feste of seynt luke ewangeliste, þe vj. yere of Edwarde þe þyrd after þe conqueste.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of Aliȝ wynnynge of Brodebluntesdon of londys & tenementes in Crickelade.

ARGUMENT.P: 1390/1, March 23. Quit-claim to Godstow, by Alice Winning, of all title in property.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of this chartur is, þat aliȝ wynnynge of Brode|bluntesdon surrendred to þe Abbas & couent of Godestowe all þe state, þat she had of the same Abbas & couent, of all londis & tenementes þat she had in þe towne & feldes of Crickelade; re|mittid & relesid Also, to þe same abbas & couent, all accions bothe reall & personall þat she myht haue a-geyniste hem fro þe bi-ginnynge of þe worlde vn-to þe dai of þe makynge of þis present writinge: in-to wittnes of þe whiche she put to her seel, þe date vppon shere thursdaiShere Thursday is Th. in Holy Week., fallinge þe thursdai a-fore þe fest of þe annunciacion of owr lady, þe xiiij. yere of þe reine of kinge Richard þe secund aftur þe conqueste.

ARGUMENT.P: [NOTE.—At the dissolution, 1540, this property is put down (Monast. iv. 374) as yielding Godstow £1 10s. yearly, and subject to a quit-rent of 2s. to the rector of Eddyngton. Eddington is a long way to the south-west: so possibly Hannington is meant.]

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of warine of ailisbury I-made to Roger of writele & to anneis his wife of ij. yerdes londesIn error for '1 yerde of londe.' & vj. acris, with a mese, in worthe and Esthrop, paiinge þerof yerli for alle seruices vj. d at Mihel-mas.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Sale to Roger of Writele, by Warine of Ailisburi, of a mes|suage, a yardland, 6 acres of 'echyng,' and pasture rights. Description of the yard|land:— 10 whole acres and 20 half|acres and 2 roods = 20½ acres. Description of the six acres 'of the heche' = 2 acres, 5 half-acres, and 7 'butts' (irregular pieces). Quit-rent, 6d. Relief reserved. Free of scutage. Purchase|money, £26 13s. 4d.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat warine of ailisburi gaf, grauntid, & confirmid, to Roger of writele of brodebluntesdon & to anneis his wyfe & to his heires or assynis, j. yerde londe in þe towne of Esthorp, with a mese, with all oþer þinges ouer all perteininge þer-to, þe wiche walter of alfrinton helde sum-time in þe same towne, with all his pertinences in euiri place, & liberteis, in medis, closis, pasturs, weijs, patthis & in all oþer places euiri-where; & of þe encreseAbove encrese, echyng is written as a gloss. The Latin is: 'et de incremento sex acras terre de dominico meo in dictis campis de Estthorp.' vj. acris of londe of his demayne in þe seide felde of Esthorp; with þe pastur of on oxe in þe commune pasture of oxen of Esthrop: of þe whiche yerde londe (& also of þe vj. acris):—

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of waryne of ailisbury I-made to Roger of writele of j. yerde of londe & vj. acris of his lordeship as hit is conteinid in þe chartur be|fore.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Cancelled draft of no 820. Proposed purchase-money, £25 6s. 8d.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of this chartur & confirmacion is þe same þat is wrete next afore, with þe pasture of on oxe; & for this confirmacion he had xxx. viij. marke of siluir a-fore|handis.

DIV5.HEAD: a-noþer chartur of warine of ailisburi of þe same, for þe which Roger of writele payd [x]xxxvij. marke & x. shillings.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Cancelled draft of no. 820. Proposed purchase-money, £25 3s. 4d.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis chartur is þe same afore senten|cialli almost euiri worde.

DIV5.HEAD: a-noþer confirmacion of þe same warine for þe same londe, acris, mese, & her pertinencis.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Cancelled draft of no. 820. Proposed quit-rent, 4d. Proposed purchase|money, £23 6s. 8d.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis confirmacion is conteinid in þe chartur a-fore, with a condicion to pai iiij. d of siluir at mihelmas, for all seruices, seutes of courte, plaintes, customs, aidis, wardis, herriettes, eschetes, & for all seruices vtwarde, sauinge to hym & to his heiris resonable relefe: & for þis gifte, graunt, & con|firminge, þe fore-seide Roger gaf [xx]xv. marke of siluir bi-fore hondes.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of Adam of ailisburi I-made to Roger of writele confirminge þe gifte of warine his fadur.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Confirmation of no. 820, to Roger of Wri|tele, by Adam of Ailisburi. Quit-rent, 10d.

DIV5.P: THE sentence is þe same a-fore, with a condicion to pay yerli x. d for all maner of customs & seruices: & furþermore in þis confirmacion Roger of writele hadd powere, more-ouir, bothe in sekenes & in helþe, to gif þe seide londe a-fore rehersid to religius howsis or where him lustid.

DIV5.HEAD: A graunt of Thomas of Maundeuile of fre entringe in þat tenement.

ARGUMENT.P: 1284, Aug. 25. Licence in mortmain, by Thomas de Mande|ville, as chief lord of the fee, allowing Godstow to receive from Roger of Writele no. 820. Purchase|money, £1.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis graunt is, þat Thomas Maundeuile grauntid, for him & his heiris for euir, to þe worshopfull woman of religion dame Mabili, abbas of Godestowe, & to þe couent of þe same place, fre entringe in-to all þat tenement, with þe pertinences, þat [s]he had of þe gifte & feffement of Roger of writele in heiworth & in Esthrop of his fee, with-oute ony ageine-seinge or lettinge of him or of his heiris, sauinge þe seruices of þe fore-seide tenement dewe & wonid to him & to his heiris. For þis graunte þe foreseide abbas gafe xx. shil|lings of sterlinges. In-to witnes þer-of he put to his seele: þe date at heiworthe, þe freday next aftur seint bartholmewys day, þe xij. yere of kynge Edward þe sone of kynge henri.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of hugh Maundeuile I-made to Roger of writele of j. yerde of londe in fre socage, with a mese & a crofte in þe towne of Esthrop, painge þerof yerli ij. shillings at iiij. termis of þe yere.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Grant to Roger of Writele, by Hugh of Mandeville, of Ralph Castell's yardland, subject to 2s. quit|rent. Purchase|money=giving up a lease, and £2 13s. 4d.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat hugh of Maundeuile fitȝ Philip of Maundeuile gafe, grauntid, & confirmid, to Roger of writele of bluntesdon & to his heiris or assinis, for homage & seruice, in-to fre socage, all þat yerde-londe þat Raph castell sumtime helde of him in þe towne of hyworthe (þat is to sei, in Esthrop), with j. mese and crofte & with oþer pertinences & liberteis, in medis, feldis, pastures, weijs, pathis, & in all oþer places euiry-whare, with-oute ony withholdinge to him & to his heiris, to be had & to be holde, of him & of his heiris, to þe fore|seide Roger of writele, & to his heiris or assinis, for to assine, gife, sille or bequeþe to whom so-euir he will & whenne-so-euir he wille, boþe in sekenes & also in helþe, in fee & heritage, freli & quietli, well & pesibli, for riht heritage for euir, with-out ony lettinge reclaiminge or vexinge of him or of his heiris here|aftur, painge yerli þerof to him & to his heiris ij. shillings of siluir at iiij. termis of þe yer, þat is to sei, at þe natiuite of our lorde, vj. d; at estur, vj. d; at Midsomer, vj. d; & at Mihelmas, vj. d, for all seruices, & sutis of his courte, playntes, customis, aidis, wardis, eschetis, & seculer demaundis longinge
to him & to his heiris, sauinge to him & to his heiris resonable relef: & þe same hugh warantiȝid & acquitid for euir þe fore|seide yerdlonde, with all oþer þinges a-fore rehersid, ageinist all men & women þat miht in ony case aske ony þinge þerof. And for þis gifte graunt & confirmacion & warantiȝinge, þe seide Roger relesid to him iiij. yerde londis & ij. parties of j. yerde-londe þat he hilde of him to ferme to þe terme of viij. yere, with all his mese in þe same towne of heyworthe, & also he gafe to him iiij. marke of siluir a-fore-handis: and for-asmuche þat he wolde þat his gift, graunt, confirmacion & warantiȝinge, sholde be ferme & stable for euir, he strengthid hit with þe printinge of his seele: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: Graunt & confirmacion of heli of Maundeuile I-made to Roger of writele of j. yerde londe.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Confirmation to Roger of Writele, by Elias de Mande|ville of no. 826.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis euidence is þe same þat is next a-boue, with an addinge to, þat he miht gife hit to religious howsis, bothe in sekenes & in helthe.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur & confirmacion of heli of Maundeuile to dame Mabili abbas of Godestowe & to þe couent of þe same place for to take entre in-to þe same yerde-londe, with þe pertinences, & þe rente of ij. shillings.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1284. Licence in mortmain by Elias de Mandeville, allowing Roger of Writele to give and Godstow to receive no. 826, free (as in no. 829) of the 2s. quit|rent over it.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat heli of Maundeuile grauntid to the worshipfull wemen, dame Mabili, abbas of Godestowe, & to þe couent of þe same place, fre entre in all þat yerde-londe, with þe pertinences, þat þei hadde of þe gifte of Roger of writele in þe towne of hiworthe & esthrop, þe whiche þe same Roger helde of him. Furþermore he gafe relesid & quite-claimid vtturli, of him & of his heiris for euir, to þe fore|seide dame mabili abbas of Godestow & her couent all his rent of ij. shillings þe whiche Roger of writele was I-wonid to pay him for þe fore-seide yerde-londe, to be had & to be holde of him & of his heiris or his assinis, to þe fore-seide mabili abbas & to here couente & to here successours, freli quietli well & pesibli for riht heritage for euir, painge þerof yerli to him & to his heiris or to his assinis j. halfe lj. of comin at estur, for
all seruices & seculer demaunde: & þe same helie, his heiris, and assinis, warantiȝed acquitid & defendid þe foreseide yerde|londe for euir ageniste all men & women. Forþermore, for þis gifte & warantiȝinge þei gaf to him xx. shillings of siluer a-fore|handis for warisone. In-to witnes of þis þinge he sette to his seele: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: A Chartur of helie of Maundeuile of ij. shillings of yerli rente.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1284. Sale to Godstow by Elias de Mandeville, of the 2s. quit-rent,as in no. 826 and no. 828. Quit-rent now is to be ½ lb. of cumin. Purchase|money, £1.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat helie of Maundeuile fitȝ hugh of Maundeuile gafe & grauntid, for him & his heiris or his assinis, to god & to the churche of our ladi & of seint Iohn baptiste of Godestowe & to þe minchons þer seruinge god & to serue for euir, ij. shillings of yerli rente þe whiche he was wonid to receiue yerli of Roger of writele for a yerde-londe þe whiche he had of þe gifte of hugh his fadur in þe towne of hiworthe & Esthrop, to be had & to be holde, of him & of his heiris or assinis, to god & to þe churche of Godestowe & to þe minchons in þe same seruinge god & to serue for euir, freli, quietli, well & pesibli, with-oute ony reclaime or ageineholdinge to him & to his heiris or assinis, painge þerof yerli to him & to his heiris or his assinis half a lj. of comin for all exaccion & seculer demaunde at estur. For þis gifte graunt & quite|claime, þei gaf to him xx. shillings of sterlinges good & laufull monei a-fore-handis. Forþermore, he, his heiris, or his assinis, acquited and defendid, to þe fore-seide churche of Godestowe & to þe mynchons þer seruinge god & to serue for euir, þe fore|seide rente of ij. shillings ageiniste all men and women with her owne costis. In tokin þer-of he put to þis present writinge his seele: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: Charter of Richer Tarilari of a messuage and croft, made to Roger of Writele, paying 1d. at Easter.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Draft of a grant to Roger of Writele, by Richard Tarlari, of a messuage and croft, in exchange for a mes|suage and on pay|ment of £2 13s. 4d. (see no. 831).

DIV5.P:
RICHER Tarlari, of Estrop in Heyeworth, gave, to Roger of Writele of Bluntesdone and his heirs and assigns, a messuage in Heyeworthe with a croft and pertinents, namely that mes|suage which lay between the messuage which was of Warin
of Eylesburi and that of Thomas of Stanton, paying yearly 1d. of silver at Easter for all services, suits of his court, quarrels, customs, helps, wards, escheats, and secular demands belonging to him and his heires, and free of foreign service, but reserving reasonable relief: and for this

confirmacionThe English Register resumes after loss of a leaf., þe seide Roger gafe to him j. mese in þe seide towne of Esthorpe in-to eschaunge, & foure marke of siluir bi-fore-handis, þat is to sey, þat mese þat was sumtime of walter of alfrinton: &, for þat he wolde þat his gifte graunt confirmacion & warantiȝinge sholde be sure & stable for euir, he strengthid hit with þe printinge of his seele: & is with-oute dateWitnesses: Walerand of Bluntesdon; Roger de la Buri; Peter of the mill; Peter of Eylesburi, &c..

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of Richarde tarlari I-made to Roger of writele ofj. mese with a crofte in þe towne of esthrop & of ij. acris of londe with on perche, painge þer-of yerli j. d at Mihelmas.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Grant to Roger of Writele, by Richard Tarlari, of mes|suage, croft, four half|acres, and one rood, in exchange and on pay|ment of £4 6s. 8d.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of this chartur is, þat Richard'Richerus' in the Latin. of tarlari, of Esthrop in hiworthe, gaf, grauntid, & confirmid, to Roger of writele & to anneis his wife & to his heiris or assinis, for his seruice, all his mese þat he had in þe towne of Esthrop in hyworthe with þe crofte & all his pertinences & fredoms, þat is to sei, þat mese þat is bitwene þe mese þat was of warine of ailisburi & þe mese þat was of Thomas of Staunton, & ij. acris & a perche of his londe in þe feldis of Esthrop, with all his per|tinences & fredoms, þat is to sei, j. halfe acre at Ellecumbe, þe whiche lieth nih þe londe þat was of warine of ailisburi; & j. half acre in stotfurlonge, nih þe londe þat was of þe seide warine of ailisburi; & j. halfe acre at litilcoldeforlonge, þe whiche lithe nih þe londe þat was of Richard dolle; & j. halfe acre in deneknedishull, nih þe londe þat was of the seide Richard dolle; & j. perche vppon doune in whale-hull'Walehull' in the Latin., þat lieth nih þe londe þat was of Iamis of worthe: to be had & to be holde, of him & of his heiris, to þe seide Roger & anneis his wife: & so forthe, worde for worde, as hit is write a-fore in þe
chartur: & for þis confirmacion þe seide Roger & anneis gaf to him a-fore-handis j. mese in þe towne of Esthrop & vj. marke & j. halfe of siluir, & Richard made hit sure with his seele: & is withoute dateWitnesses: Roger de la buri de Blun|tesdon; Peter of the mill; Warin of Eyles|buri; Nicholas de gardino; Jeffrey de Maundeville, &c..

DIV5.HEAD: Chart r of Richard of tarlari I-made to Roger of writele of ij. acris of londe with on perche painge þerof yerli j. d at Mihelmas.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Cancelled draft of no. 831. Reference to no. 809.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis chartur is þe same that is a-fore; except j mese, ofthe whiche here he makith no men sion.

LOKE þe chartur of Roger of writele bacwarde a-monge þe charturs of bluntesdon, in þe whiche the same Roger gaf to þe house of Godestowe all his londis & tenementes in brode|bluntesdon, Esthrop, & Cheleworthe.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of Roger of writele to seyson the abbas of Godestowe Dame Mabili in all his londis & tenementes with her pertinences in hyworth & Esthrop.

ARGUMENT.P: 1284, Aug. 22. Letter of attorney, for no. 833.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis dede is þat Roger of writele ordeinid his welbelouid in criste Roger brien his attornei to put the worship|ful women of religion, the abbas of Godestowe, Dame Mabili, & þe couent of þe same place, in-to full seyseninge of
DIV5.NOTE1: [Leaf XXXIIII in the old paging is missing.]
DIV5.P: [the lands he had in Heyeworthe and Estthrop which he gave to them. Given at Bluntesdon, Wednesday before St. Bartholomew, 12 Edward I.]

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of a gift & graunt of Thomas tarlari of j. mese withe ij. acris of londe & j. rode I-made to þe minchons of Godestowe in hyworthe & in Es|throp.

ARGUMENT.P: 1284, Aug. 26. Licence in mortmain by Thomas Tarlari, as chief lord of the fee, empower|ing Roger of Writele to give, and Godstow to receive no. 831. Fee for the licence, 10s.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat Thomas tarlari was welle I-content & plesid of þe gifte & graunt þat Roger of writele made to þe worshipful women of religion, Dame Mabili, abbas of Godestowe, & to þe couent of þe same place, of j. mese, ij. acris
& j. rode of londe, with þe pertinencis, in Worth & Esthrop; grauntid for him & his heiris, & confirmid for euir, þe same þinges a-fore rehersid, þe whyche þe fore-seide Roger helde sum-time of him: & for þis graunt & confirmacion, þe foreseide abbas gaf to him x. shillings of sterlinges. In-to witnes of þis, he put to his seele, þe date at Worth, þe saturday next aftur seint bartholomewe feste, þe xij. yere of þe reine of kinge Edwarde þe sone of kinge henri.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of kynge Edwarde of a mese & londe in Esthrop.

ARGUMENT.P: 1284, Oct. 5. Licence in mortmain by Edward I, allowing Roger of Writele to give to Godstow a plough|land in Eastrop, i.e. in High|worth and Blunsdon, and allow|ing God|stow to receive it.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis chartur is þat edwarde, bi þe grace of god kinge of Inglonde lorde of Irelonde & Duke of gyen, þow þat he, bi his commune cownsell of his reme, prouidid þat hit sholde not be lefful to religious pepul or to oþer to entre þe fee of ony man so þat hit sholde come to morte-maine, with-oute his leue & licens & of þe chefe lorde of þe whiche þat þinge was I-holde inmediatli, Netheles he, willing to do special grace & fauor to Roger of writell, gaf to him licens, al so muche as was in him, þat he miht gife & assine to his welbelouid abbas in criste & to þe minchons of Godestowe a plowh-londe, with þe pertinences, in heiworth & bluntesdoune, to be holde & to be had to hem & to her successours for euir: & he grauntid also to þe same abbas & minchons licens þat þei miht receiue þe fore-seide londe of þe fore-seide Roger so, bi þe tenoure of þese present writinges: & he wolde not þat þe same Roger or a-fore|seide abbas and mynchons sholde be occasionid or lette þerof, bi him or bi his heiris, bi the reson of þe statute a-fore-seide in ony wise or be a-greuid, yet sauinge þe seruices dewe & wonid þerof to þe chef lordis of þe fee. In-to witnes of þis þinge he lete make his letturs patentes, him-silfe beringe witnes at 'mounteIn the margin, hawte mount is written. hie' þe fifte day of october, þe xij. yer of his reine. I-commaundid to þe chaunceler de monte alto.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of adam of Eilisbury fitȝ warine of a place, crofte, curtilage & j. hole halle.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1280. Sale to Sarah of Mandeville, by Adam son of Warin of Ailesbury, of house and lands, held by quit-rents of gilt spurs and 1 lb. of cummin. Purchase|money, £13 16s. 8d.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat adam fitȝ warine gaf grauntid & confirmid, for him & his heiris & his assinis for euir,
to Sare of Maundeuile to her heiris & assinis for euir, his place, crofte, curtilage, & with þe hole howse þat he had in the towne of Esthorp, þat is to sei, þat place þat wareine his fadur sum|time helde, with þe crofte, curtelage, & þe hole halle, & oþer pertinences (sauinge þe Est party of þe crofte þe whiche Richard castell helde a-fore of his gifte & of þe ȝyfte of william his broþer, & hit lieth nihe þe courte þat was of Roger of writele) with all his pertinences in all places, liberteis, & esimentes, to be had & to be holde of þe lorde of þat chefe fee & of his heiris in-to fre socage, to þe fore-seide sare, & to her heiris or assinis, or to ony oþer to whom-so-euir she will (in sekenes or in helþe) assine gif sille or biqueþe hit, in fre heritage, freli, quietli, well & pesibli, for riht heritage for euer, with-oute ony reteininge or lette of him or of his heiris here-aftur, painge þer-of yerli to Thomas of Mawndeuile, chefe lorde of þat fee, & to his heiris or assinis, j. paire of spurres gilte or vj. d. of siluir at esture, & at mihelmas j. lj. of comyn, for all seruices, sute of court, plaintes, aidis, wardis, homages, reconisaunces, eschetes, heriettes, relefes, & oþer seculer demandis: & þe fore|seide adam, his heiris, & assinis, warantiȝed acquited & defendid þe crofte a-fore-seide, with all oþer þinges a-fore rehersid, a-geiniste all men & women þat wolde make ony quarell a-geiniste her: & for þis gifte graunt & confirmacion & waran|tiȝinge, þe seide Sare gafe to him xx. marke of siluer a-fore hondis: &, for-as-much as he wolde þis gifte graunt confirminge & warantiȝinge sholde be sur & stable for euir, he strengthid hit with þe printinge of his seele: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of Sare of Maundeuile for a mese curti|lage & crofte in heiworþe.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1290. Sale to Godstow, by Sarah of Mandeville, of a mes|suage, curtilage, and croft, as in no. 837, subject to suit to court, and to quit-rents, as in no. 837. Purchase|money, £13 6s. 8d.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat Sare of Maundeuile gaf, grauntid, & confirmid, to þat worthi woman dame mabili, bi þe grace of god abbas of Godestowe, & to the couent of þe same place & to here successours for euir, j. mese with a curtilage & crofte in þe towne of heyworth (þat is to sei, in Esthrop), þe whiche she had of þe gifte of adam wareine in þe same towne, with alle her pertinences in all places, to be had & to be holde, of Thomas maundeuile lord of þe fee & of his heiris, to þe fore|seide
Mabile, abbas of Godestowe, & to þe couent of þe same place & to her successours, freli, quietli, well & pesibli, for riht heritage for euir, with-out ony reteininge, doinge þer-of to þe same Thomas lorde of þe fee dewe seruices & wonid to þe for|seide mese & crofte perteininge, for all seruices & seculer demaundis longinge to him & to his heiris, sauinge to þe lorde of þe fee all seruices aforeseide longinge to þe same tenement boþe in sute of courte & also in rentes, þat is to sei, a paire of sporis gilte or vj. d. at estur & j. pownde of comin at mihelmas, with þe seide sute, yerli: & þe seide Sare & her heiris waran|tiȝid acquitid & defendid to þe foreseide dame Mabili, abbas of Godestowe, & to þe couent of þe same place & to here succes|sours, all þe fore-seide tenement ageiniste all mortall men for euer. For this gifte graunt & confirminge & warantiȝinge, þe fore-seide dame mabili, abbas of Godestowe, gaf to her xx. marke of siluer in warison bi-fore handis. In-to witnes here-of here seele was put to þis writinge: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of Thomas Maundeuile confirminge þe chartur of Sare his Sistur.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1290. Licence in mortmain, by Thomas de Mandeville, as chief lord, allowing his sister to give and Godstow to accept no. 838.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis confirmacion is euin þe same worde for worde as is þe chartur of the gifte of feffement a-fore seide.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of Gefrei of Maundeuile for a mede longinge to þe halfe acr e.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1290. Grant to Godstow, by Jeffrey of Mande|ville, of a mea|dow, and pasture|right.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat Gefrei of Maundeuile gaf, grauntid, & confirmid, to Dame Mabili Wafre, abbas of Gode|stowe, & to þe couent of þe same place, in-to pur & perpetuel almis, all þe mede longinge to on half acre in þe felde of hiworþe, þat is to sei, in þe mede þat is callid estmede onder|mede & toddenei in partinge of þe mede of þe same abbas, with þe halfe of þe pasture of j. oxe in þe fre pasture of Esthrop, with all his pertinences & fredoms in euiri place longinge to þe fore-seide mede & pastur, to be had & to be hold to þe fore-seide abbas & couent & to her successours, freli & quietli, well and pesibli, for riht heritage for euir, with-oute ony withholdinge, &
[fre] fro all seculer seruices or demaunde: also þe foreseide Gefrei & his heiris warantiȝid acquitid & defendid, to þe foreseide abbas & couent & her successours, all þe foreseide mede & pasture, with all þe pertinences, agenist all mortall men. In-to witnes þerof he put to his seele: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: Charter of Nicholas de Gardino of a half-yard|land of land, made to Roger of Writele, paying one halfpenny of silver and a lb. of cummin at Michael|mas.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Sale to Roger of Writele, by Nicholas of the Garden, of a half|yardland and mea|dow:— viz. in one field, 10 half|acres, 4 roods, 3 half|roods, all separate, and, in another field, 6 half|acres, 3 roods, and 3 sellions, allseparate; in all about 11 acres. Quit-rent ½d. and a lb. of cummin. Purchase|money, £7 6s. 8d.

DIV5.P: NICHOLAS de Gardino granted, to Roger of Writele and his heirs and assigns, a half-yardland of his land in the fields of Worthe, namely that which he had of the gift of Matilda the daughter of Everard le pestur, with all the mead belonging to it, namely in Estmed, Sundermed, Rowendene, Eldelonde;

a half-acre in North field in Rugfordelonde next the land which was of John Everard; a half-acre in Waterforn south|wards, next the land which was of Robert of Abindone; a half|acre at þickeþorne, next the land which was of John Penot; one rood in Gerbrodelonde, next the land which was of William Torn; and a half-acre under rigge, next the land which was of Jeffrey of Mandeville; a half-acre at Rowendene, next the land which was of Robert of Abindone; [a half-acre at þickeþorneMarked for correction: 'next the land which was' ought to have followed.] of Humphrey asse; a half-acre in Luttlechaldeforlong, next the land which was of William Bassat; a half-acre towards Gren|linche, next the land which was of Hugh of Mandeville; one rood at Wattoneshurne, next the land which was of Warin of Eylesburi; a half-acre at Garstonesȝete, next the land which was of William Bassat; one rood under Budewelle, next the land which was of Eruald Wypping; a half-rood at Dracȝurde, next the land which was of Robert of the mill; a half-rood at Holeweye, next the land which was of Robert Ref; a half|rood there next the land which was of William Torn; a half-acre at benche, next the land which was of John Everard; one rood at Settelþorne, next the land which was of John Everard.

In South field, a half-acre at Reuerdesforlonge, next the land which was of John Aylewyne; a half-acre over Sevenhemehull, next the land which was of Roger Castel; a half-acre in in|londe, next the land which was of Ralph Castel; one rood there, next the land which was of William Torn; a half-acre in Wowelonde, next landewe; a half-acre towards heyemore, next the land which was of Ralph Castel; one rood at Holelake, next the land which was of Jeffrey de Mandeville; a half-acre under gurefeu, next the land which was of John Everard; one rood at Wydihamme, next the land which was of Hugh of Mandevile; three 'sullones' in a croft at Korpeswelle.

All these he granted to Roger of Writele, his heirs and assigns, to be held by payment of a half-penny of silver'unus obolus argenti.' and a lb. of cummin at Michaelmas for all services, except reasonable relief. For this grant Roger of Writele paid 11 marcs of silver. Witnesses, Warin of Eylesburi, Roger of Laburi, Peter of the mill, etc.

DIV5.HEAD: Quit-claim of Hubert de Gardino of Worthe.

ARGUMENT.P: 1284, Aug. 26. Quit-claim to Godstow, by Hubert of the garden, of all title in no. 841. Purchase|money, 13s. 4d.

DIV5.P: HUBERT de gardino quit-claimed to Mabil, abbess of Godstow, and the convent of Godstow, all right and title in a half-yardland, with meadow belonging to it, in Worth and Estthrop, which they had of the gift of Roger of Writele, and which the said Roger had of Hubert's father Nicholas de gardino. For this grant Godstow paid him a marc of silver.
Witnesses:—Richard de la Ryvere, and John Waleraund, knights; Thomas of Maundevill; John of Wydhull, etc. Given at Heyeworthe, Saturday after St. Bartholomew, 12 Edward I.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of Roger writele of brode bluntes|dunne of londys & tenementys.

ARGUMENT.P: 1285. Duplicate of no. 809. Grant to Godstow, by Roger of Writele, of all his lands and manorial rights in Broad Blunsdon, Eastrop, Highworth and Chal|worth, out of which £2 is to be spent as a pit|tance on his anni|versary. Godstow is to give Roger, his wives, his parents and his bene|factors a place in the prayers of the com|munity.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of thys chartur is, that Roger writele of brode bluntysdoune, by the assent & consent of anneys hys wyfe, gafe grauntyde & confermyde with hys wrytynge, & claymyd vtturly
to be quite for hym & hys heyrys, to god & to þe churche of our lady seynt Marye & of seynt Iohn baptiste of Godestowe & to þe mynchons there seruynge god & to serue for euyr, for the helthe of hys sowle & of anneys hys wyfe & Isabel sum|tyme his wyfe & for þe soules of here fadurs & modurs & of all benefeturs, in-to fre & perpetual almys, all hys londys in brode bluntysdone & in Esthrop & in þe towne of heyworth & in chelworþe, with þe mansions, bildynges, gardynys, doffe|howsys, fre tenauntes, bounde holders with her sequelis (or hem þat folowe of hem), coterell, rentes, workes, helpis, wardys, relefys, eschetes, fynys of londys, a-geyne-byynges of her pro|geniturys, medys, pasturys, scuages, sutys of courtys, with all oþer liberteis & fre customys longynge to all þe seyde londys in all þe seyde places, with-out ony ageyne-holdynge to hym & to hys heyrys or to ony in þe worlde, & with all þat myht falle to hem or to hys heyrys or to ony other by ony Ryht, all þe seyde londys to be holde & to be had, with all þyngys per|teynynge to þe same, to þe fore-seyde churche of Godestowe & to þe seyde mynchons ther seruynge god & to serue for euyr, frely pesybly & holly for euyr, of þe lordys of þe fees, doynge þer-of to hem seruices dewe & wonyd, þe whych he dyd or was wonyd to do for þe fore-seyde londys for all þynges & euyrych þyng perteynynge to hem: also he gafe to þe fore-seyde myn|chons yerly, in þe day of hys anniuersarie, xl. shillings to a pitaunce in-to a memorye of hys sowle: & for þys gyft graunt & confirmacion & quite-clayme, þe foreseyde abbas & mynchons receyuyd specially hys sowle, & þe sowlys of anneys & of Isabel hys wyfys, fadurs & modurs sowlys, & of all hys benefeturs, in all her suffrages, prayers, almys & vigils for euyr: & þat þys gyft graunt & confirmacion & hys quite-clayme sholde byde sure stable & unbroke for euyr, he put to hys seele: & is without date.

DIV5.HEAD: The Charter of William Bonyfaunt of Seven|hampton I-made to Roger of Writele of an acre of lond with a perche, paiyng therfor yerely j. d. at Estir.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1270. Sale to Roger of Writele, by William Bonyfaunt, of 1 acre, 1 rood; quit-rent, 1d.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of this Charter is, that William Bonyfaunt of Sevenhampton, the sone of Everard Baker, yaf and graunted,
and with his owne chartir confermed, to Roger of Writele of Bluntesdon and to his heires or to his assignes, for his service, an acre of his lond and a perche in the feldes of Seven|hampton, that is to sey, j. acre at Wodepole liyng togedir bitwene the lond of the demayne of Sevenhampton and the lond that was of William Elmer, and a perche liyng beside Morlplotte bitwene the lond of the demayne of Sevenhampton and the lond of William Elmer: to be holde and to be had, of hym and of his heires, to the said Roger and to his heires or to his assignes who-so-ever they be and whom-so-ever he willed assigne yeve or bequeth, bothe in sikenesse and in helthe, in fee and in heri|tage, fre and quyetly wele and in pease, without ony lette or ony reclayme or vexyng of hym or of his heires here-after, paiyng therfor yerely to hym and to his heires j. d. of siluer at Ester, for all seruyces, sutes of his Court, quareles or playntes, customes, helpes, releves, wardes, Eschetis, and
DIV5.NOTE1: [A leaf is missing]
DIV5.P: [other secular demands. William Bonyfaunt warrantizes said acre and rood to Roger of Writele. For this grant Roger gave him 20s. before-hand to his great need Witnesses:— Peter of the mill, Warin of Eylesbury, etc.]

DIV5.HEAD: A Charter of Symond Louel, fitȝ William Louel, I-made to the mynchons of Godestowe, for all the londe with the principall or chief mese and with all other pertynentis that he bought and had som|tyme in the towne of Vffecote.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1200? Grant to Godstow by Simon Louel, of land of the bishop's fee.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of this charter is, that Symond Louel, fitȝ William Louel, yaf, & cetera, to god & cetera and to the myn|chons of Godestowe ther seruyng god, for the helthe of his soule and of the sowles of his fadir and modir and the sowles of his brethern and his susteren, all the lond with the chief mese, the hole of possessions of frutes and all other frutes and profites and all liberteis that euer hit had best and freliest, savyng the bisshoppes right in all thyngis. And that this his yifte
shold not fro that tyme be reuoked by ony machynacion or shrew, he confermed the same pagynei. e. pagina, used as equivalent to 'document.', and strengthed hit with the defence of his seale. These beyng witnesse, & cetera.
DIV5.NOTE1: [NOTE.—The Latin copy (Exchequer MS. leaf 151, back) shows that the translator in condensing the document, has left out matter of importance. The witnesses were 'Sir' Philip Lovel, 'Sir' William of Torney, and 'Sir' Richard of Henton, probably parish clergy. The land (4 virgates) was bought from Robert Toky, and held subject to a quit-rent of 12d. at Easter. The sum of 5s. was to be spent as a pittance to Godstow on the donor's anniversary day, and the rest of the income to be given to the use of the kitchen of Godstow. At the dissolution, 1540, God|stow still owned some small revenue at Ufcot, but it is slumped with revenues from Cricklade, &c.: Monast. iv. 374.]

DIV5.HEAD: Of a half-virgate in Uffecote.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1200? Grant to Godstow, by Simon Lovel, of a half|yardland.

DIV5.P: SIMON Luvell gave to Godstow the half-virgate in Uffecote, which Walter, son of Gunuld, gave to him.
Witnesses:—Peter of Meyroles; Thomas of Uffecote; Philip Luvel, cleric.

ARGUMENT.P: [NOTE.—In pope Nicholas IV's 1291 Taxatio Ecclesiastica Godstow is put down as receiving in spiritualities a portion of £2 yearly from Eaton chapel (probably the lesser tithe, see no. 851), and in temporalities £20 from properties in Cricklade and Eaton. In the survey of 1531 (Monast. iv. 373) the properties in Nun-eton or West|eton and in Broad Blunsdon are assessed to be worth £60 a year.

In Mr. J. Horace Round's Peerage and Family History (1901), pp. 201-6, these Godstow deeds are brought in to explain the grantor's family history. Reginald fitz-count, was son of Roger fitz-William, earl of Hereford, who died in prison in 1087. Mr. Round thinks him a legitimate son, excluded from the earldom, because that was forfeited by his father's rebellion. He held property in Wilt|shire in right of his wife, Emmeline, daughter and heiress of Hamelin de Ballon, lord of Abergavenny.]

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of Reinolde of þe maner of Eton.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1142. Grant to Godstow, by Reginald fitz-count, of the manor, confirmed by king Stephen.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of this chartur is, þat Reinold fitȝ erle, & Emeline his wyfe, & his sones Reinolde & hameline, & his dowhters anneis & Iuliane, gaf, & grauntide, to god & to our ladi, & to seint Iohn baptiste & to the holi minchons of Gode|stowe, in-to perpetuel almis, his maner, þat is to sei, Eton,
as well & worshipfulli, freli & quietli, in all þinges & in all places, as euer he helde beste in þe time of kynge henry or of kynge Stephin, þe which also grauntid & confirmid this gifte bi his chartur for þe sowle of kynge henri & for her sowlis at the beginninge rehersid & for þe sowlis of her aunceturs: & is with-oute date.
DIV5.NOTE1: [The preceding deed and no. 850 are printed in Monast. iv. 365 from the Latin.]

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of Reinolde fitȝ Roger Erle of herford for þe maner of Eton.

ARGUMENT.P: 1145. Restate|ment of no. 847. Grant to Godstow, by Reginald son of Roger, earl of Hereford, of the manor of Eaton, with full manorial rights, with con|firmation by King Stephen.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat Reinolde (þe sone of Roger, Erle of herforde) & emeline his wife willid to be knowe, toMS. has 'þat,' by a slip for 'to.' þe bisshope of lincolneAs diocesan of Godstow. & all cristen men present now & for to come, þat boþe þei & his too sonis Reinolde & hameline, & also his too dowhters anneis & Iulian, gafe, & grauntid, to god & to our ladi & to seint Iohn baptiste of Godestowe, in-to perpetuel almis, to þe vse of þe holi minchons, Eton his maner of her chife lordeshippe, for her helþe & for remedi of her sinnis & also for þe sowle of kynge henry & for þe sowlis of his aunceturs. Were|fore þei willid & desirid affectuosli þat no man, bi þe deuillis meuinge, sholde be a-bowte for to lette þis gifte or uexe þe fore-seid minchons of þe fore-seide churche with ony doinges to make hem weri of hit, but þat þei holde hit & haue hit well & in peece, freli & quietli & worshipfull[i], in woode & in plaine, in medes & pasturs, in waters & millis [&] in pondis, in weiis & paþis, & in all þinges longynge to hit, with all customis & liberteis, as freli & also welle as euir þei helde hit while þat hit was in her owne honde in þe time of kynge henri & aftur|warde in kinge Stephin's time, bi whos chartur Also þis gifte of hem was confirmid, þe x. yere of his reine.

DIV5.HEAD: Confirmacion of kynge henry for þe maner of Eton.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1154. Confirma|tion to Godstow, by Henry II, of the grant of Eaton (no. 848).

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of this chartur or confirmacion is, þat henri, kinge of Inglonde duke of Normandie & of gyen & Erle of aunge, willid to be know to archebisshopis bisshopes Abbotes Erlis Iustices vicountes barons Ministres & to all his trewe
men of Inglonde, þat he grauntid to god, & to þe churche of our ladi & of seint Iohn baptiste of Godestowe, & to þe minchons þere seruinge god, þat gifte þat Reinolde fitȝ Erle & Emeline his wife & william & hameline his sonis made to þe fore-seide churche of Godestowe & to þe minchons, of þe maner of Eton, in-to perpetuel almis. Where-fore he willid & commaundid sureli þat þe foreseid churche & minchons sholde holde & haue þe fore-seide maner well & pesibli, freli & quietli & worshipfulli, in woode & plaine, with all oþer comoditeis rehersid in þe chartur bi-fore, & also freli as euir þei helde hit in her life: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of reinold baelim for þe maner of Eton.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1154. Confirma|tion to Godstow, by Reginald de Ballon, of his father's grant, as in no. 848.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis chartur is, þat reinold baelimIn error for 'Baelun,' i.e. de Ballon., þe sone of Reynold fitȝ counte alias erle, & emeline baelim, grauntid & confirmid þat gifte þat his fadur & his moodur maden of his maner, þat is to sei, of Eton, to god & to þe churche of our ladi & of seint Iohn baptiste & to þe holi minchons of Gode|stowe, in-to perpetuel almis: wherefor he grauntid & willid þat þe fore-seide minchons sholde holde & haue þe fore-seide maner well & in pece, freli, quietli, & worshipfulli, in all þinges, in wode & plaine, in medis & pasturis, in waturs & millis & pondis, in weiis & patthis, & in all oþer places, with all thinges hangynge þer-to, & all libertees & quietinges þe which þe foreseid Reinolde his fadur helde whenne þat he helde hit beste & freeste while þat hit was in his honde, and as hameline of baelim his vncle helde hit moste beste & frelieste in his life: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: a composicion bitwene þe abbot of Cicetur & þe abbas & minchons of Godestowe for þe churche of Eton.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1195. Commis|sion ap|pointed by pope Celestine III to decide suit between Godstow and Ciren|cester abbey, as to the relation of Eaton chapel to Eisey (the mother|church). Orders that (a) Eaton is to be sub|ject to Eisey as a chapel-of|ease; (b) Eaton chapel is to have land as|signed for its endow|ment; (c) great tithe of Eaton manor is to go to Eisey. (d) Renun|ciation of appeal to Rome. (e) Arable to remain arable; pasture, pasture. (f) Ser|vices in Eaton chapel are to be supplied by Eisey church. (g) Eaton chapel is to have its own church|yard. (h) Godstow is to have the lesser tithes of Eaton manor.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of this composicion is, þat þer was a delegacie I-sende fro pope celestineCelestine III was pope 1191-8. þe iij. to henri'Henry 'must be in error for 'Hugh,' possibly arrived at by wrongly expanding H. of the deed. Hugh, abbot, immediately succeeded Alfred (d. 1189), and remained abbot till his death (1221)., abbot of Abendon,
& to williamWilliam of Forde, abbot 1184-1205., abbot of Thame, & to mastur Robert Chadeles|wrde, to knowe þe cause of þe strife bi-twene RichardRichard, abbot of Cirencester 1187|1213. Cirencester abbey owned the rectory of Eisey., abbat of Cicetur & þe chanons of þe same place, & þe abbas & min|chons of Godestowe, for to cese hit with a dewe forme & ende. & so, aftur mony tretinges of þe same mater, þei compownid frendli, bi counsel of wise men, & restid bi þis ende: þat is to sei, þat þe fore-seide abbas & mynchons, þe quarel & playnt þat þei had meuid to þe fore-seide abbot & chanons vppon the chapell of Eton (seiinge þat hit was & owid to be fre & assoiled fro þe subieccion of euiri modur church) remittid hit all to þe chanons, grauntinge also þat þe fore-seide chapel of Eton sholde a-bide subiecte for euer to þe church of Eisi as a chapell. þeii. e. the Commissioners. grauntid also to þe chapell of Eton & bi hit to þe churche of Eisi (as to þe modur churche) halfe j. hide of londe in Eton biside þat halfe hide of londe þat hit holdiþe & haþe I-holde fro olde time, to be holde in-to pure & perpetuel almis, with meede & pastur perteininge to þe same, freli & quietli fro all exaccion & seculer seruice þat shold be do to þe same minchons þer-of: also j. yerd-londe þat was assinid of olde time to the same chapell with þe pertinences þat hit had of olde time, & a-noþer yerde of londe of þe lordeshipe of þe minchons in-to an eschange of a yerde of londe þat was assinid of olde time to þe fore-seide chapel, of þe whiche yerde of londe x. acris wer assinid in þe est felde in a telthe þat is callid beringereslonde, & in þe same parte of þe felde was assinid of þe demain mede of þe minchons mede perteininge to þe fore-seide yerde of londe, þat is to sei, ij. acris & j. halfe; oþer x. acris wer assinid in þe sowth felde in telthe þat is callid vedermorforlonge, in þe whiche telþe þe fore-seide minchons reteinid too vtter|muste acris next to þe pasture: thei graunte also to þe fore-seide chapell, with þe fore-seide londe, a crofte with a mese next to þe crofte longinge a-fore to þe fore-seide chapell. Thei graunte also þat, of all her lordeship in Eton, þe tithis of þe corne sholde be gyfe hole at þe doris of þe bernis to þe person of Eisi & to his successours for euir, with-oute deceite or greuance. Thei promisid also, bi a boke oth, þat þei sholde neuer aftur|warde
gete no letters fro þe pope, noþer vse non I-gote, bi þe whiche sholde ony derogacion be or hurte to þe fore-seide couenaunt, & þat þei sholde not turne þe arable londe in-to pasture or pastur in-to arable londe in-to deceite of þis coue|naunt. & þe fore-seide abbot & couent grauntid to þe fore|seide chapell of Eton þat hit sholde haue bi þe churche of Eisi all seruice þat hit was wonid to haue of ryht, þat is to sei, euiri soneday, & euiri holi day, & iij. daiis in þe woke (þat is to sei, moneday, wodynesday & freyday), & thorowe all þe lente, continuel seruice, with þe ouris of þe day in lente & holi dais to be seide. Thei grauntid also þat men of Eton sholde be biried euirmore bi þe chapelleyn of Eisi in þe churche-yerde of þe chapell of Eton, sauinge thorowe all þe riht to þe churche of Eisi þat þe fore-seide churche was I-wonid to haue in þe seide chapell, sauinge also þe bisshoppis riht & customis. Thei grauntid also to þe foreseide abbas & couent of Godestowe þat hit sholde be lawefull to hem for euir to reteine to hem-selfe þe tithis of norisshinge of bestes of here owne lordeship, & of nouall tithis, & fisshinges, & frutes of treis, aftur þat hit was gef to hem in þe priuileges of pope clement þe vRead Clement III, pope 1187-91; see in the confirmation-bull (no. 902) of Celes|tine III, circ. 1192. The Latin has 'Clementis tertii.'. Thei behestid also, bi her trowth, þei sholde not gette no þinge aftur|warde noþer vse I-gote ony þynge bi þe whiche ony gile sholde come a-geiniste þis couenaunte or be derogacion & hurtinge in ony wise: &, for-as-muche as hit is vn-semeli & a-geiniste reson þat contrauersi nameliche amonge religious folke lawfully endid sholde be soreli I-meuid ageine, þe delegates confirmid this composicion, resonabli I-made a-fore hem, bi þe autorite þat þei had: and þat hit sholde be sure for euir, thei chargid hem to make hit stronge bi þe puttinge to of her seelis to þis presente writinge: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: a conuencion I-made bi-twene þe abbot of Cicetur & his couent & þe abbas & minchons of Godestowe of þe chapell of Eton.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1195. Agreement, in terms of no. 851, between Godstow and Ciren|cester abbey, (a) as to services to be supplied by Eisey church in Eaton chapel; (b) as to Eaton church|yard; (c) as to Godstow's right to the lesser tithes of Eaton.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of þis conuencion is, þat þe abbot of Cicetur & his couent, with oon assent, grauntid to þe chapell of Eton,
þe whiche is a chapell of þe churche of Eisi, þat hit sholde haue bi þe modur churche of Eisi all seruices þat hit was wonid to haue: euiri soneday, & euiri holiday, & in euiri woke thre daijs (þat is to sei, moneday, wodenysday & freday) & thorowe all þe lente, continuel seruice, with þe oures of þe day in lente & in feriali. e. week-days. daijs to be seide. Thei grauntid also þat men of Eton sholde be biried in the churcheyerde of þe chapel of Eton euirmore bi þe chapeleyne of Eisi, sauinge þe riht þat hit was wonid to haue in the fore-seide chapell, sauinge also þe bisshopis riht & customs. Thei grauntid also to þe abbas & couent of Godestowe þat hit sholde be lefull to hem to reteine to hem-selfe þe tithis of norisshinges of bestes of her owne lordeshipis, of nouall tithis, fisshinges, & frutes of treis, as hit was gyfe to hem in þe priuileges of pope clement þe iij. and of pope celestine þe iij. Thei promittid also bi her trwthe þat þei wolde neuer gete noþer vse I-gote ony thynge þat sholde cause þis couenaunt to be broke: & þat þis couenaunt sholde a-bide sur & stedefaste, þei strengthid hit with her seele: & is with-oute date.

DIV5.HEAD: Agreement between Godstow and Thomas of Sanford, as to exemption of Eaton manor from suit to his hundred-court.

ARGUMENT.P: 1222? Quit-claim to God|stow, by Thomas of Sanford, exempting Eaton from suit to the hundred of Staple, in consi|deration of £4 13s. 4d.

DIV5.P: THOMAS of Sanford quit-claimed, for himself and his heirs, to Godstow, all suits of their manor of Eaton to his hundred of la Stapele. In return Godstow, at the charge of the convent, is to withdraw an action raised by it in the king's court. A penalty of 20 marcs is agreed upon, to be paid by him or his heirs, if he or they withdraw from this bargain; and he or they must also refund the 7 marcs which Godstow has paid him for it. Witnesses: John de Lupello; Stephen of Hare|hull.

DIV5.HEAD: a final concorde of þe sute of þe hundred of Thomas of StapultonThe Latin copy has 'Stapelton' in the rubric, but in the text 'Thomas de Saun|ford,' 'Thomas de Stapel,'.

ARGUMENT.P: 1222. Draft quit-claim to Godstow, by Thomas de Saun|ford of Stapel, exempting Eaton manorfrom suit to the court of his hundred, in con|sideration of a place in Godstow prayers.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of þis writinge is, þat þer was a concorde I-made in þe kinges cowrt at westminster fro þe day of seint
Mihel in-to j. moneth, þe yer of kinge henry þe sone of kinge IohnThe Latin copy has after Johannis an obscurely written word like soytod. It is probably sexto, i. e. 1222. The names of the justiciaries agree with that date., a-fore Thomas of miletteIn the Latin: Thomas of Milet. (i. e. Muleton), William of Ral. (i. e. Raleigh), Robert of Shard. (i. e. Shardelow)., william of RaleIn the Latin: Thomas of Milet. (i. e. Muleton), William of Ral. (i. e. Raleigh), Robert of Shard. (i. e. Shardelow)., Robert of lexinton, william of yorke, Mayster Robert [of] ShardeIn the Latin: Thomas of Milet. (i. e. Muleton), William of Ral. (i. e. Raleigh), Robert of Shard. (i. e. Shardelow)., & Raph of Northewiche, Iusticis, & oþer trewe men of þe kinges þere beinge presente, bi-twene Thomas of Stapulton, plainer, & an|felice of Godestowe, defender, bi Reinolde [le] porter in her stede to gete or to lese, of þe seutes, þe whiche þe same Thomas axid of þe same abbas to þe hundred of þe same Thomas of Stapulton, of þe maner of þe same abbas of Eton, þe which seutes þe same Abbas knowlich notte hem & of þat same þat hit was pleid bi-twene hem in þe fore-seide courte. þe fore-seid Thomas remittid & quite-claimid, of him-self & of his heiris, as muche as longid to hem, to þe fore-seid abbas & to oþer abbassis succedinge her & to her churche of Godestowe, þe fore-seide seutes, so þat afturwarde forþe þe seide abbasses sholde be quiete of all maner seutes longynge to þe fore-seide hundred for euir: &, for þis quite remittinge claime fine & concorde, þe fore-seide abbas remittid & quite-claimid, of her & of oþer abbasses succedinge to her, to Thomas & to his heiris, all þe harmis þat she seid þat she had bi þe fore-seide occasion: & þe seide abbas receiuid þe seide Thomas & all his heiris in alle benefetes & prayours þat sholde aftur þat time in her churche of Godestowe be don for euir.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur for tithis of hei & millis ageiniste þe person of Eisi.

ARGUMENT.P: 1236. Commis|sioners appointed by pope Gregory IX, Perugia, 1236, July 9, to decide in suit by Eisey church for tithes of hay and mills of Eaton manor, assign to Eisey, in lieu of such tithes, 3 acres of meadow and 3 quar|ters of corn yearly

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of this euidence is, þat, bi pope gregori, was a maundement made to þe prioris of NewnehamNewenham in Goldington parish, Bed|fordshire. & of Calde|well & to þe dene of bedeforde of lincoln diocese, vppon the bisshop of seint dauid, abbas & Couente of Godestowe, & oþer of lincolne seint Dauid & of Salisburi diocesis, for wronges þat were done to þe person of þe churche of eisy, for certeyn tithis & possessions & oþer thinges. For this þe pope commaundid to her discrecion, bi his writinges, þat þei sholde calle þe partes to-gedur & her her causes, appellacion put a-side, & so to make
an ende; & þat þat þei ordeinid, to be kepid bi þe autorite of þe pope; the witnes þat sholde be namyd, yf thei with-drawe hem-selfe for fauor or hatered or drede, þat thei sholde constreine hem bi þe censures of þe churche to sei þe trowþe, the appel|lacion sette a-syde; & þat, if all miht not be þere, [þ]at tweyne of hem at leste sholde do execucion: the date at peruse, þe xvj. kalend of auguste þe ix. yer of his popehode. At þe laste, in þe church of seint poule of bedford, þe abbas & couent ofte timis I-citid, þe tiwisday next aftur seint Matheu þe apostil þei apperid a-fore vs in Iugement, bi william, chapleine, her pro|curator sufficientli ordeinid in Iugement; Master Nicholas, actor, person of Eysy proposinge his entent, þat is to sei, þat where he proposid & axid, bi þe autorite of þe pope, of þe same abbas & couent, þe tithis of hei & of millis of þe demaine of þe seide abbas & couent in Eton longynge to his churche of Eysy, bi the commune lawe. Aftur mony altercacions bi-twene hem, þe strife cesid vndur þis forme: þat is to sei, þat þe seide abbas & couent grauntid to þe seide churche of Eysy iij. acris of mede in fordemede bi-side hidemede, for þe goodenes of peece & cause of stryfis to be made lesse & cesid, in Eton of þe demayne of þe seide abbas & couent for euir: & furþermore þei grauntid to þe fore-seide church of Esy for euir iij. quarters of commune corne yerli, þat is to sei, euin as hit comith to the mille, with-oute ony gyle or deceite yerli to be take at thre termis of þe yere, þat is to sei, at candelmas, on quarter at þe seide mille of Eton; & j. quarter, at midsomur; & at Mihel|mas, j. quarter. Boþe parteis, bi her feyþe & trowthe, assinid in her presence þis composicion truli to be kepid & wiþe-oute deceit; & þei þat wer iugges, bi þe autorite þat þei had, with þe consent of þe parties, confirmid þe same, reseruinge to hem Iurisdiccion to constreine þat parte þat wolde not kepe hit. In-to witnes of þe which þynge, þei put to her seeles, with þe selis of þe parteis also: & is with-oute date.
DIV5.NOTE1: [NOTE.—That wheat sent 'to the mill' was expected to be or a recognized standard of purity is confirmed by a curious tradition which survives in Essex from the times before agricultural machines. Elderly men tell me that, in their boy|hood, the wheat-crops were much infested by darnel (lolium temulentum). When the wheat was thrashed, each sheaf, before it was passed to the thresher, was taken in hand by a boy, who pulled out the darnel-heads. If this was not done, the miller either refused to buy the wheat, or gave a very small price for it.]

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of þe tithe of þe hey of Eton.

ARGUMENT.P: 1296, May 3. Agreement by Roger of Writell, perhaps tenant of Eaton manor, to pay the vicar of Eisey yearly 10s., during his tenancy, in lieu of tithes of hay.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of þis euidence is, þat, in þe yer of our lorde Mo CC lxxxxvjo, at Estur, hit was a-cordid bi-twene Mastur william Brachell, person of þe churche of Eisi of þe on parte, & Roger of writell of þe oþer parte, þat syth þat þe'þe' is marked for deletion. maystur william a-fore-seide had drawe þe same Roger in-to plee in cristin courte, in axinge of þe same Roger tithis of hei of þe maner of Eton Minchons oþer-wise þen he was wonid to haue: þe same Roger grauntid, to þe fore-seid maistur william, euiry yere to pay x. shillings of siluer at þe feste of seint petur þat is ad vincula or lambemas, while þat he had þe lorde-shipe of þe maner of Eton; & þe seide Maistur william grauntid to þe same Roger to cese fro all axinge of hei of þe seide Maner of Eton, bi the name of tithis as longe time as he had possession of þe lordshippe; & þe fore-seide Roger, for þis peticion to be relesid, paid to þe seide William'Roger,' in error in MS. x. shillings of siluer for þe yer þat was a-passid. In-to witnes of this same her seelis wer putt to þis writinge, euirich a-geiniste oþer: þe date at Eton Minchons, in feste of þe inuencion of the cros, the yere a-fore-seide.

DIV5.HEAD: Chartur of kynge Edwarde of Mereheued at Eton.

ARGUMENT.P: 1306/7, Febr. 12. A Wilt|shire jury having presented Godstow, at the assises, for stop|ping a branch of Thames, thereby damaging queen Margaret's lands at Latton, Edward I ordered the sheriff of Wiltshire to have the case tried. Godstow denied the charge, and before the jury of Latton proved the existence of old stepping|stones, and the case was dropped.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of þis euidence is, þat kynge Edwarde sawe þe tenour of recorde & processe of a presentment a-fore hys wel|belouid & trewe men, Iohn of lee & his felowis Iustices, I-assinid to here & to ende diuerse transgressions harmis greuis & excessis in wilton sher þat wer do þat time, vppon þe abbas of Gode|stowe, þe which he made to come bifore him in his chauncellarie; wiltesir sessions: praesentatum est peri.e. 'per duodecim bonos et legales homines.' xij. þat abbas of Gode|stowe, bi xij. yer a-passid, in þe time of þe kinge, stoppid a course of watur in temyse I-callid Morheued with-in the liberteis of þe quene of lacton & turned þe cowrse of watur to þe noiinge of þe foreseid quene & of all þe cuntre & cetera: and hit was commaundid to þe shreue þat he shold make come
þe foreseide abbas, a-fore Iohn at lee & his felowis, Iustices & cetera, at hegworth, þe wodeinsday aftur þe feste of seint Mathew þe apostle, to answere þe kinge & cetera: and þe abbas, bi Iohn Mondi her attornei, come þen & seide þat þe abbas was lady of þe maner of westetonThe Godstow manor is variously called Water-eaton, West-eton, Nuns-eton, Eton|mynchons, to distinguish it from the adja|cent Castle-eaton., þe whiche maner she helde as of þe riht of her abbei, þe whiche maner is with-in þe lordeshipe of þe quene; froIn the Latin 'Absque hoc': i.e. she dissented from the presentment, viz. that she had caused. þat, þat she leuied or causid ony noiinge or turnid ony course of watur as hit was presentid afore, & þat she is a-redi to verifie. Ideo preceptum est vicecomiti þat he sholde make heRead 'hem' or, better, omit. come bifore þe seide Iustices at Marleborowe, þe moneday next aftur þe feste of seint lucie virgin, dei.e. 12 good men of the Latton view|of-frankpledge, to act as sworn jury. visu de lacton & cetera xij. & cetera, per quos & cetera, to þe recognicion in forme a-fore-seide. At þe whiche day þe fore-seide abbas come bi her attornei, & Iuriorsi.e. attended. The Latin is 'et iurati similiter.' also, þe whiche seide vppon her othe þat þe foreseide abbas helde þe maner a-fore-seide as of þe fundacion of her churche; also þei seide þat þer wer of olde time certen stonis [placedAdded from the Latin. It goes on 'these stones were to the advantage of all passing there or having lands and meadows there, and that neither the abbess nor any of her predecessors caused any nuisance there.' at the Mereheued, and with iron and lead] Ioinid to-gedur to þe ese & profite of þe pepul goinge or hauinge hereRead 'þere.' londis & mede, & þat noþer þe fore-seide abbas ne none of her predecessours did no noiinge þere noþer with-in þe maner a-fore-seide noþir turnid þe course of þe watur as hit was supposid. þerefore þe fore-seide abbas may go fro þe courte dailesi.e. 'day-less': in Latin 'sine die,' the formula used when no further proceed|ings were to be taken., sauinge þe kingis riht. And þe Iustices, at þe requisicion of þe fore-seide abbas, made þe tenoure of þe recorde & processe a-fore-seid to be exemplified bi þese presente writinges. In-to witnes of þe whiche þe kinge made his letters patentes, him-selfe beinge witnes at westminster, þe xij. day of feuerelRead 'feuerer.', þe xxxv yere of his reine.

DIV5.HEAD: A Charter of Helye fitȝ Robert for all his right that he had in all his londes in yorke, & cetera.

ARGUMENT.P: Confirma|tion to Godstow, by Elias, son of Robert, of lands in Littlegate, given by his brother Thomas.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of this charter is, that Helie fitȝ Robert graunted, & cetera, to god & cetera and to the mynchons of Godestowe ther seruyng god, into pure and perpetuel almesse, for the helth of his soule and of his auncetours, all the right that they had at york in all the londes in litelgate, the which lieth bitwene thirosegail and the lond of henry Bustard, the which they had of the yifte of theire bretherne Roger and Thomas, frely and quyetly fro all seculer seruyce and exaccion except the seruyce of the chief lord, that is to sey, ij. shillings by the yere for all seruyce, and except j. lj. of comyn the which were I-woned to pay the mynchons afore-named to hym and to his heires for all seruyce at Cristmasse, after the tenour of the charter that they had of Thomas his brother. And his brother warantiȝed þise aforsaid londes to the forsaid mynchons, after the charter of Thomas his brother afore-named. These beyng witnesse, & ceteraNo other trace of this property has been found..

HEAD.HI1: PLACES UNIDENTIFIED WHEN THE MS. WAS FIRST SENT TO PRESS

DIV5.HEAD: Charter for 20s. rent in Adelinkton.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1145. Grant to Godstow, by Muriel de Bohun, of a rent|charge, to found an obit.

DIV5.P: MURIELLA de Boun gave 20s. rent in Adelinkton, viz. in Dereseth, which William son of Bricher used to pay to her, to be paid to the kitchen on her anniversary.
Witnesses: Herbert, chaplain and keeper of Godstow; James, steward of Godstow; Magister Rogerus Glovernia.
DIV5.NOTE1: [NOTE.—Identification supplied by Rev. H. E. Salter. In 1200 the bishop of Salisbury held, as two knights' fees, five small manors, viz. Prinnesley, Piddle Athelampston, and three others. At an earlier date Muriella de Bohun, wife of Ralph de Bruere, occurs as giving away land in Prinnesley (Hutchins's History of Dorset, iv. 298.]

DIV5.HEAD: Charter of Thurstan, dispensator of the king of England.

ARGUMENT.P: 1234, Nov. 29. Grant to Godstow, by Thurstan Despencer, of a rent|charge, to endow an obit on Sept. 9 for his son Amalric.

DIV5.P: THURSTAN Despencer, with the consent of his wife Lucy, gave to Godstow 5s. of yearly rent for the soul of Amauri his son, viz. 3s. to be taken of his men of Bradenston and his fee in that vill with the homages, and 2s. in Baldindon from Andrew of the chequer, to provide a pittance on the morrow of the Nativity of the Virgin, i. e. on the anniversary of Aumari his son.
Witnesses: Ralph Despencer, parson; Adam Despencer, knight; Absalom and Bernard, chaplains; Gilebert of Biham; Reoland Bluet. Eve of St. Andrew, 1234: at Godstow.
DIV5.NOTE1: [NOTE.—Rev. H. E. Salter identifies both places for me. Baldindon is Baldon, Oxfordshire, where the Despencers had a manor of six hides. Broad-enstone is a hamlet, in Enstone parish, Oxfordshire, which was held, by the Despencers, of the Abbot of Winchcombe.]

ARGUMENT.P: [NOTE.—The mention of the bishop of Lincoln suggests that this place was in that diocese, and it has been therefore assumed to be Combe Longa by Woodstock in Oxfordshire. The witnesses (Exchequer MS. leaf 183, back) supply no clue to the locality, being Hugh, chaplain; Ralf of Monemut. (i. e. Monmouth: Canon of Lincoln, circ. 1150-80); Sayer of Quincey; Fulk Trussell, &c. The date is also fixed by the absence of the property from pope Eugenius III's confirmation, 1145, and from Henry II's first confirmation, 1156, and its presence in Henry II's second confirmation (no. 879), 1165. Against the identification with Combe Longa is the fact that the manor of Combe Longa was in the King's hands from 1154 on|wards; so that its miller, in making his grant, would have appealed to the King, his overlord, not to the bishop. The extant accounts of the manor (in Public Records Office) are not early enough to help us. Rev. S. Spencer Pearce, Vicar of Combe, tells me that there is no mention of the mill in the accounts 1243-99, but in those of 1304-11 it is plainly in the King's own hands.]

DIV5.HEAD: A Charter of Norbert for the mylle of Combe I-made to the holy mynchons of Godestowe.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1160. Norbert, donor of the mill to Godstow, asks the bishop of Lincoln, Robert (de Chesney), bishop 1147-68), to effect his purpose.

DIV5.P: THE sentence of this Charter is, that Norbert willed to be know to the Robert Bisshop of lyncolne fadirhode and to all trew cristen peple of the chirche, that he, for the helthe of his sowle, yaf and graunted into perpetuell almesse, to god and to the chirche of oure lady of Godestowe and to the holy mynchons there seruyng god, his mylle of Combe with all that longith therto. Wherfor he besily praied his hyghnesse that he wold maynteyn and defende the same holy mynchons, for the love of god, in the same almesse. These beyng witnesse, & cetera.

ARGUMENT.P: [NOTE.—Among the witnesses are Walter and Jordan, chaplains, and Walter Maleth. Herring were cured at the fishing-port. Oseney, e.g., Rev. H. E. Salter tells me, had tenements at Dunwich and at Yarmouth for the supply of herrings. Margaret, wife of Hugh de Cressi, in 1175 inherited Horseford manor from her father William de Chesney. It had belonged to the family since 1086 (Blomefield's History of Norfolk, x. 433).]

DIV5.HEAD: A Charter of Margery Cressy, I-made to the mynchons of Godestowe, for v. cartlode of wode of aldur of her wode I-called horforde, xv. dayes after myghelmasse yerely to be take, to dry ther heryng.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1180. Grant to Godstow, by Margery Cressy, widow, of wood at Michael|mas to dry their herring.

DIV5.P:
THE sentence of this charter is, that Margery Cressy, in her fre wedowhode, for goddis sake and for the helth of her
sowle and of the sowles of her fadir and modir and of her aunceturs and successours, graunted, & cetera, into pure and perpetuel almesse, to god & cetera and to the mynchons of Godestowe ther seruyng god, v. cartlode of wode of Aldur'de alno in bosco meo de Horsford' in the Latin. in her wode I-called horford to be take by yere, that is to sey, xv. dayes after myghelmasse, to drye there heryng'ad suum allec siccandum': herring being then in the midst of their season. The nuns probably bought a considerable quan|tity to dry for winter use. Herrings were brought up the Thames in barges, and, during Lent, Abingdon Abbey claimed toll of each barge so laden (Wood's City of Oxford, i. 427).. And that this her graunte, & cetera.

DIV5.HEAD: Charter of Peter of Brumelingham for the mill of Humesworth.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1160? Grant to Godstow, by Peter of Brumelingham of a mill and a rent-charge.

DIV5.P: PETER and his wife Felicia, gave, with their daughter to be a nun, their mill of Humesworth Writing indistinct: possibly 'Hinnes|worth.' See Highworth mill, in no. 886 § 59. and 2s. of rent at Hespes.
Witnesses:—Wacheline, abbot of Abingdon; Nicholas, monk of Evesham; Magister Roger and his nephew Simon; and the donor's sons William and Hugh.

DIV5.HEAD: Charter of Alan de Leia for 5 acres in perpetual alms.

ARGUMENT.P: About 1190. Grant to Godstow, by Alan of Leigh, of five acres in Petham, in exchange for a rent|charge.

DIV5.P:
ALAN of Leigh lets all men, French and English, know, that with his daughter Amphelisia to be a nun, he has given to Godstow, with consent of his son and heir Roger, five acres which lie above the house of the parson of St. Peter of Far|ningeham on the east, which acres belonged to the mill of Farningeham, and which Godfrey son of Godwin of the bridge held of him in exchange for that half-marc of rentThis rent-charge, given by Alan of Leigh, is found in Henry II's third charter (no. 886), 1182. which Richard of Grai used to pay to the nuns in the tenure of Putham,
as he has held the land, or as his lord William of Einesford held it who gave that land to him with his sister Maud in free marriage (in libero matrimonio).
Witnesses:—William, dean of Wortun (? Horton); Elias, cleric of Einesford; Thomas, nephew of Agnes the abbess: at Einesford.
DIV5.NOTE1: [NOTE.—Rev. H. E. Salter happily identifies these places. Horton-Kirby, Farning|ham (church dedicated to SS. Peter and Paul), and Eynsford are adjacent parishes, south of Dartford in Kent. Petham is a small manor in Farningham parish (Hasted's History of Kent, i. 300).]

DIV5.HEAD: Grant of the advowson of the church with all its pertinents.

ARGUMENT.P: 1234, Nov. 29. Grant to Godstow, by Thurstan Despencer, of the ad|vowson of Vleberne, to found two obits.

DIV5.P: THURSTAN, dispensator domini regis Anglie, with the wish of his mother Alde Bluet and of his wife Lucy, granted to Godstow the jus patronatus of the church of VleberneEwelme, Oxfordshire, is the only De|spencer advowson in the Testa, 1240, which is at all like Vleberne (or Uleberne). The witness Ralph Despencer was rector of Ewelme., as soon as a vacancy occurs, the fruits to go to the kitchen of the convent on the morrow (Sept. 9) of the Nativity of Mary, to keep the anniversary of Ammaurice his son (who is buried at Godstow); if Godstow procures the appropriation of the church, one half is to be applied for his son's anniversary (as before), and the other half is to go to the kitchen on St. Valentine's day (Feb. 14), to keep the anniversary of AmmauriceAlmaric Despencer, flor. temp. Ric. I. his father. Dated 1234, vigil of St. Andrew.
Witnesses:—Ralph Despencer, parson; Adam Despencer, knight; Gilebert of Biam; Reoland Bluet.

DIV3.HEAD: [1. By the bishop of Lincoln (the diocesan).]

DIV4.HEAD: A pryuylege I-grauntid by þe bysshope of lincolne'Walter, archdeacon of Oxenforde' followed, but is partially erased: see next paragraph. to the churche of Godestowe for certeyn fredams & not to be visit.

ARGUMENT.P: 1138/9. Grant to God|stow, by Alex|ander, bishop of Lincoln, with assent of Walter, arch|deacon of Oxford, of exemption from enter|taining the archdeacon on his visita|tion tour; of free hallow|ing of chrism and oil for extreme unction; of power to withdraw their chaplains from the juris|diction of archdeacon and rural dean, and dismiss them of their own authority; of subjection of the nuns to the sole au|thority of the abbess; of free election by the nuns at each vacancy of the abbess|ship. Anathema against infringers of this grant.

DIV4.P:
THE sentence of thys dede is, that, in the dedicacion of the churche of Godstowe, Alexander, bysshoppe of lincolne, in the presence of Stephyn Kynge of ynglonde & Malde quene, & a-fore Bysshopys & Abbotys, Dukys & Baronys, Clergye & also the Layfe that wher there, grauntyd to the same churche of Godstowe a liberte or fredam that sueth, I-wrete & confermyd by autorite of hym that was bisshop, walter archedecun of Oxenford beynge welwyllyd & praynge, the whiche that tyme had the offyce of archedecunrye of the same cuntre:—that is to sey, that the forseyd churche be free & vtturly restyd fro all exaccion or grevaunce of the archydiacon, as in hospitalites' the fredom þat we have of þe bisshop,' in margin. to be kepyd, or chapeleyns to be callyd in plee, or in othyr mynstyrsseSic. of the same to be browht in-to plee: Also that the seyd churche haue oyle, creyme or crisme, and holy oyle, Also oyle of seke folkeLatin is: 'oleum quoque, crisma et oleum sanctum et oleum infirmorum.', with-out payment: The abbas also may sett her chapellayns so that, yf she wylle, they go not to seynysLatin is: 'ad sinodos.' or to chapiters, nothyr that they answere the archedecun ne deene ne othyr ministers of hem but by her free wylle; &, if they wylle do frowardely, the Abbas may calle the prestys next whyche she lykyth to her owne churche, by whoos dome she may correcte hem or put hem awey: The Abbas also to haue cure & charge of her Mynchyns & correccion, with-out'¶ marke welle þys poynt': marginal note. citacion
